channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Quiet Diplomacy to Save the Olympics in a Nuclear Standoff
item.media:description: A visiting North Korean band leaving a welcoming ceremony for the country’s Olympic athletes in Gangneung, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: Organizers worried that the North would spoil the Winter Games in Pyeongchang. But after months of anxiety and failed diplomacy, there was a deal.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ, CHOE SANG-HUN and REBECCA R. RUIZ

item.title: Far From Winding Down, Syria’s War Escalates on Multiple Fronts
item.media:description: A Syrian Civil Defense member carrying a wounded child in the besieged town of Hamoria, in Eastern Ghouta, last month.
item.description: The conflict has broken into several small wars, and the carnage is reaching a new peak, upending any assumptions it might be nearing an end.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Art Looted by Nazis Gets a New Space at the Louvre. But Is It Really Home?
item.media:description: Paintings looted or bought by German occupiers during World War II were recently put on display together at the Louvre in Paris.
item.description: The museum is displaying the work in two new rooms. Critics praise the effort but say it does little to reunite the paintings with their rightful owners.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Chengdu Journal: First Rule of Chinese Fight Club: No Karaoke
item.media:description: A fight club in Chengdu, China, which goes by the English name “Monster Private War Club.”
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: In Chengdu, the owners of the “Monster Private War Club” want to make fighting cool. But to stay open, they also need to keep it respectable.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: South China Sea Photos Suggest a Military Building Spree by Beijing
item.media:description: Subi (Zamora) Reef in November.
item.description: China has spent years establishing military outposts on a group of contested islands in the South China Sea. New photos offered a detailed look.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and MIKKO TAKKUNEN
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: South Korean Leader to Meet Kim Jong-un’s Sister in Highest-Level Contact in Years
item.media:description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea at an International Olympic Committee meeting in Gangneung on Monday.
item.description: In North Korea’s dynastic system, Kim Jong-un’s sister, Kim Yo-jong, wields clout that cannot be matched by any other member of the political elite.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Norovirus Cases at Olympics More Than Double, Moving Beyond Security Staff
item.media:description: A security point at the Gangneung Olympic Park on Wednesday. The highly contagious norovirus has spread beyond the security personnel who were the first known to have contracted it.
item.description: The number of cases has risen to 86, and the virus may be traveling quickly across other Olympic areas.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: International Criminal Court Will Investigate Duterte Over Drug War
item.media:description: A complaint filed to the International Criminal Court calls President Rodrigo Duterte the “mastermind” of a campaign of extrajudicial killings in the Philippines.
item.description: The Hague-based tribunal said it would gauge whether there was enough evidence to build a case against the Philippine president for crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Bermuda Outlaws Gay Marriage, Less Than a Year After It Became Legal
item.media:description: Tourists in St. George’s, Bermuda, in 2015.
item.description: The British overseas territory adopted a domestic partnership law, instead, but gay rights advocates dismissed it as a “separate-but-equal” measure.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Sister of North Korean Leader Arrives in South Korea for Highly Symbolic Trip
item.media:description: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, left, and his sister Kim Yo-jong in Pyongyang in April.
item.description: Her three-day trip is to include a meeting with President Moon Jae-in, the highest-level inter-Korean contact in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Asian Markets Follow Wall Street’s Lead in a Broad Sell-Off
item.media:description: A display outside a securities firm in Tokyo showed Friday morning’s stock market drop.
item.description: Shares from Tokyo to Hong Kong to Shanghai fell sharply, a move that many analysts saw coming after a big run-up in recent months.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: How We Achieved an Olympic Feat of Immersive Journalism
item.media:description: View of figure skater Nathan Chen in AR.
item.description: The Times’s newsroom, design and product staffs collaborated to bring Olympic athletes, at scale and midperformance, into your living room.
item.dc:creator: GRAHAM ROBERTS

item.title: Ethiopia to Free 746 Prisoners
item.description: Among the prisoners to be freed are a journalist and a senior opposition official who were jailed for conspiracy to commit terrorist acts, the attorney general’s office said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Winter Games, Syria, Rob Porter: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: North Korean Orchestra Gives an Emotional Concert in the South
item.media:description: The North Korean Samjiyon Orchestra performing in Gangneung, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: Musicians played K-pop, Mozart, Josh Groban and other popular hymns. For some in the audience, it was their first time seeing North Koreans.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Winter Olympics’ Security on Alert, but Hackers Have a Head Start
item.description: Some computer systems connected to the 2018 Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea, have already been compromised, experts said. The big question is what happens next.
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: 2 of ISIS’ Infamous British Fighters Are Captured by Syrian Kurds
item.media:description: A member of the American-backed Syrian Democratic Forces in October inside a prison built by Islamic State fighters in Raqqa, Syria. The group is said to have detained two Britons infamous for their role in torturing Westerners.
item.description: The men were part of a notorious group of Islamic State militants known as the “Beatles” because of their British accents.
item.dc:creator: ADAM GOLDMAN and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Netanyahu Lashes Out as Israeli Police Wrap Up Graft Inquiries
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with his wife, Sara, in Davos, Switzerland, in January. He faces two corruption investigations.
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused a police chief of “mendacious” insinuations against him. Critics say he is trying to discredit the investigations.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: What South Koreans Really Think of the Olympic Thaw
item.media:description: South Koreans holding “unification flags” at a hockey game between South Korea and North Korea in 2017. The two Koreas will have a joint women’s hockey team at the Games.
item.description: One reader said it’s humiliating that South Korea isn’t marching under its own flag. Another said her grandfather might see his North Korean family again.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by KELLY VIRELLA

item.title: Upgraded Designs Unveiled for Road Tunnel Near Stonehenge
item.media:description: Stonehenge draws hundreds of thousands of visitors each year.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The aim is to upgrade a highway in the county of Wiltshire, in southwest England, to address concerns that the landscape could be scarred and irreparably damaged.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Iran Plays Down Report That U.S. Secretly Asked for Talks on Prisoners
item.media:description: Babak Namazi spoke at a news conference in Vienna in April. His father, Baquer Namazi, pictured left, and his brother Siamak, right, were convicted by an Iranian court in 2016 of collaborating with a hostile power.
item.description: The American inquiries were rejected, an official in Tehran said. “They have shown themselves as dishonest,” he added, “so what is the use of new talks?”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: U.S.-Backed Coalition in Syria Strikes Pro-Assad Forces
item.media:description: United States Air Force jets flying above Syria this month.
item.media:credit: Colton Elliott/U.S Department of Defense, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Americans say the coalition repelled an attack by forces backing President Bashar al-Assad in a rare confrontation between groups that have both fought ISIS.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Rising Hummus Prices? Blame a Drought Half a World Away
item.media:description: Limited supplies of chickpeas have combined with rising demand for hummus in Britain to send prices there 12 percent higher than a year ago.
item.media:credit: Craig Lee for The New York Times
item.description: Poor crops of chickpeas in India have made the dish more expensive in British supermarkets, the latest example of extreme weather affecting global food prices.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Two Koreas, Split by War, Use Olympics to Make Rare Shows of Unity
item.media:description: North and South Korea have formed a joint team in women’s ice hockey for the Pyeongchang Olympics. The combined squad played an exhibition match against Sweden on Sunday.
item.description: Despite clashes, North and South Korea have learned to use the Olympics to find something that still eludes them in the real world: a moment of solidarity.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Heads Up: The Beating Heart of London’s Most Dynamic Art Scene
item.media:description: In the art hub of Peckham, this bubblegum pink installation in an old car park was commissioned by the arts organization Bold Tendencies.
item.media:credit: Andy Haslam for The New York Times
item.description: The Peckham neighborhood is on the circuit of art world bigwigs for its combination of art with $1-million price tags and vibrant creative scene.
item.dc:creator: GRACE BANKS

item.title: Analyzing North Korea’s Parade Plans
item.description: Satellite imagery shows how the North Korean authorities have mobilized and trained tens of thousands of people for a military parade ahead of the Olympics.

item.title: Few Challengers in Sight, Venezuela Sets April 22 for Presidential Vote
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela. His government announced Wednesday that a snap presidential election would be held on April 22.
item.description: The election puts the unpopular administration of Nicolás Maduro in the hands of voters at a time when most top challengers have been barred from running.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Letter 44: Why We Need a New ‘Crocodile Dundee’
item.media:description: On set with the new “Dundee” sequel?
item.description: Movies define countries. Australia and its relationship to the world needs an update.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Mexico Reports Record Number of Illegal Taps Into Fuel Pipelines
item.description: Fuel thieves in Mexico drilled 10,363 illegal taps into state-owned pipelines in 2017, or an average of about 28 every day.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: More Than 300 Child Soldiers Freed in South Sudan
item.description: The United Nations is working to win the release of more child soldiers in South Sudan, but all sides in the country’s civil war are believed to have recruited more than 19,000 children as fighters.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Schumer, North Korea, Los Angeles Times: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: On Northern Syria Front Line, U.S. and Turkey Head Into Tense Face-off
item.media:description: American Special Forces soldiers arrived at a front-line outpost outside the northern Syrian city of Manbij on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The New York Times traveled with two U.S. generals to a northern Syria city where armed conflict between the Americans and Turks is now a possibility.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: In Sweeping War on Obesity, Chile Slays Tony the Tiger
item.media:description: Kiosks in Santiago’s city center feature products with black nutritional warnings on the labels of items high in sugar, salt, calories or saturated fat.
item.media:credit: Victor Ruiz Caballero for The New York Times
item.description: New regulations, which corporate interests delayed for almost a decade, require explicit labeling and limit the marketing of sugary foods to children.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: ‘Cheddar Man,’ Britain’s Oldest Skeleton, Had Dark Skin, DNA Shows
item.media:description: A likeness of “Cheddar Man,” Britain’s oldest complete human skeleton, at the Natural History Museum. Genetic evidence showed that he was dark-skinned and blue eyed, scientists said.
item.description: New research adds to a growing body of evidence showing how the British Isles received waves of immigrants over tens of thousands of years.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and CARL ZIMMER

item.title: With Former In-Laws in Custody, Father Gains Leverage in Brazil ‘Parental Abduction’ Case
item.media:description: Nicolas Brann
item.description: The arrest of the parents of a Texas man’s ex-wife is a rare instance of Brazilians facing criminal charges in the United States stemming from a custody battle.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Justin Trudeau Regrets ‘Peoplekind’: ‘I Made a Dumb Joke’
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in Ottawa on Monday. His cabinet has an equal number of men and women.
item.description: After the Canadian prime minister was shown on video telling a woman not to say “mankind” at a town-hall-style meeting, people had many, many opinions.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH

item.title: Beirut Journal: Walking Tour of a City’s History, Assassinations Included
item.media:description: After a four-year absence, Ronnie Chatah has revived his tours of Beirut, Lebanon. They cover the city’s long and often painful history.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: Ronnie Chatah, who leads the tours, considers them a tribute to the city and to his father, who was killed by a car bomb in Lebanon in 2013.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Corruption Inquiry Draws Nearer to Former Chinese Prime Minister
item.media:description: Duan Weihong, also known as Whitney Duan, is one of China’s wealthiest women. She was detained last fall before a Communist Party congress.
item.description: The detention of Duan Weihong is a sign that President Xi Jinping’s anticorruption campaign may be closing in on a former top leader.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: A Korean Olympic Dilemma: Do Hockey Sticks Violate U.N. Sanctions?
item.media:description: Anti-North Korea activists protesting on Tuesday at Mukho Port in Donghae, South Korea, near a ferry that brought musicians, dancers and singers from the North to perform at the Pyeongchang Olympics. North Korean ships are usually banned from the South’s waters.
item.description: Officials in the South are struggling to accommodate the North’s Olympic delegation without breaking international rules.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Narendra Modi’s Estranged Wife Escapes Unhurt From Car Crash in India
item.media:description: Jashodaben Chimanlal in 2014. A retired teacher, she was married to Mr. Modi about 50 years ago, but the relationship was kept quiet for decades.
item.description: Jashodaben Chimanlal, whose marriage to the prime minister was kept quiet for decades, was involved in a collision in which a relative of hers died, the police said.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Curious About the Lives of North Korea’s Isolated Athletes? Here’s a Glimpse
item.media:description: Only two North Korean athletes — the figure skaters Ryom Tae-ok and Kim Ju-sik — qualified for the Pyeongchang Olympics on merit.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: We’ve gathered insights from the country’s state news media, analysts, defectors and athletes who have competed alongside North Koreans.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Angela Merkel Strikes New Deal With Old Partners, at a High Cost
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin on Wednesday with Horst Seehofer of the Christian Social Union, center, and Martin Schulz of the Social Democrats, right, after talks to form a coalition government.
item.description: The agreement, subject to the approval of members of the Social Democratic Party, came at a steep price for the Christian Democrats: giving up the powerful Finance Ministry.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Influential Sister to Visit South Korea for Olympic Ceremony
item.media:description: Kim Yo-jong, the sister of Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, in Pyongyang last year. She will arrive in South Korea on Friday as part of North Korea’s 22-member government delegation to the Winter Games.
item.description: Kim Yo-jong will be the first immediate family member of North Korea’s ruling dynasty to set foot in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Success of Russia’s Female Figure Skaters Takes a Toll in Injuries and Stress
item.media:description: Evgenia Medvedeva competing at the European Figure Skating Championships in January in Moscow. She is widely expected to win a medal in women’s singles skating at the Winter Games.
item.description: The bodies of Russia’s young female skaters are breaking down as they push their performance in pursuit of gold medals and more difficult jumps.
item.dc:creator: JERÉ LONGMAN

item.title: Taiwan Earthquake Toll Rises to 9 Dead, With Dozens Missing
item.media:description: A building teetered Wednesday after its first floor collapsed in an earthquake in Hualien, in Taiwan’s east.
item.media:credit: Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: The 62 people reported missing are believed to be trapped in buildings damaged by a magnitude-6.4 quake.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: As Trump Wavers on Libya, an ISIS Haven, Russia Presses On
item.media:description: The Libyan militia leader Gen. Khalifa Haftar, center, on Russia’s only aircraft carrier in January 2017.
item.description: In the absence of a coherent American policy for Libya, Russia is gaining influence in one of the most dangerous parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
